query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
1 «Osanna, sanctus Deus sabaòth, 2 superillustrans claritate tua 3 felices ignes horum malacòth!».
query.result:
**English:**
1 "Hosanna, holy God of hosts, 2 supremely illuminating with your brightness 3 the blessed fires of these heavens!"
**Cornish:**
1 "Osanna, sans Deus sabaòth, 2 ow goleuys yn ughella gans dewdhek, 3 an tanow benygys a'n malacòth-ma!"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
10 Io dubitava e dicea ‘Dille, dille!’ 11 fra me, ‘dille’ dicea, ‘a la mia donna 12 che mi diseta con le dolci stille’.
query.result:
**English:**
10 I hesitated and said, ‘Tell me, tell me!’ 11 to myself, ‘tell me,’ I said, ‘to my lady 12 who used to comfort me with her sweet words.’
**Cornish:**
10 Yth ommdhewth ha leverel, ‘Lever, lever!’ 11 orth y’m, ‘lever’ leverel, ‘dha’m benen 12 a wra vedha’m gans dha gerensoweth melys’.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
13 Ma quella reverenza che s’indonna 14 di tutto me, pur per Be e per ice, 15 mi richinava come l’uom ch’assonna.
query.result:
**English:**
13 But that reverence which took possession 14 of me, even for Beatrice and for her sigh, 15 weighed me down like a man who is drowsy.
**Cornish:**
13 Mes an reverens ma a wra gesys 14 a-ugh oll annav, rag Be ha rag ys, 15 a wra’m pessa orth y den a wra kowsys.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
16 Poco sofferse me cotal Beatrice 17 e cominciò, raggiandomi d’un riso 18 tal, che nel foco faria l’uom felice:
19 «Secondo mio infallibile avviso, 20 come giusta vendetta giustamente 21 punita fosse, t’ha in pensier miso;
22 ma io ti solverò tosto la mente; 23 e tu ascolta, ché le mie parole 24 di gran sentenza ti faran presente.
query.result:
**English:**
16 Beatrice bore with me for a short while 17 and began, beaming at me with a smile 18 that would make a man happy in the fire:
19 “According to my infallible judgment, 20 how just vengeance was justly 21 punished, has put you in thought;
22 but I will quickly free your mind; 23 and you listen, for my words 24 will make you aware of a great truth.
**Cornish:**
16 Beatrice a wra’m pessa orth y’m bys vyth 17 ha commensys, ow th’y wra skynnys gans gwelyn 18 avel, a wra gweles den lowen bys vyth:
19 “Herwydh y’m barn diwrians heb faýl, 20 pythvel venjans a veu venjys yn just, 21 a wra’th ow settys y’th poynt a-ugh y’th galon;
22 mes y’th leverys y’th poynt a-ugh y’th galon; 23 ha thowgh klev, rag y’m gerow a wra 24 a wra gweles dynerth meur a-ugh y’th galon.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
25 Per non soffrire a la virtù che vole 26 freno a suo prode, quell’ uom che non nacque, 27 dannando sé, dannò tutta sua prole;
28 onde l’umana specie inferma giacque 29 giù per secoli molti in grande errore, 30 fin ch’al Verbo di Dio discender piacque
31 u’ la natura, che dal suo fattore 32 s’era allungata, unì a sé in persona 33 con l’atto sol del suo etterno amore.
query.result:
**English:**
25 In order not to submit to the virtue that desires 26 a bridle for his own good, that man who was not born, 27 condemning himself, condemned all his offspring;
28 whence the infirm human race lay 29 down through many centuries in great error, 30 until it pleased the Word of God to descend
31 where nature, which had become distant from its maker, 32 united itself to him in person 33 with the sole act of his eternal love.
**Cornish:**
25 Rag na wra soffrya dhe’n vertus a wra goul 26 fren rag y’i profys, an den a veu genys, 27 ow dannans y honan, a wra dannys y oll y los.
28 Rag henna an den spys a-ugh an den a veu kleves 29 a-ugh termyn meur yn faýl meur, 30 bys henna a veu lowen dhe’n Ger a-ugh Duw dhe dhyskynna
31 le mayth an naturel, a veu a-ugh y Grewr 32 a veu a-ugh y honan a-ugh person 33 gans an gwrians hepken a-ugh y gerens karantek.

**English:**
34 Now turn your face to that which is now being discussed: 35 this nature, united to its maker, 36 as it was created, was pure and good;
37 but of its own accord it was banished 38 from paradise, because it turned away 39 from the path of truth and from its life.
**Cornish:**
34 Mes lemmyn tro dha drem dhe’n tra a wra leverys: 35 an naturel ma a veu unys dhe’n Grewr, 36 pythvel a veu crys, a veu pur ha da.
37 Mes rag y honan a veu a-ugh y honan banys 38 a-ugh paradys, rag henna a droes 39 a-ugh fordh an wiryonedh ha a-ugh y byw.

**English:**
40 Therefore the suffering that the cross inflicted 41 if measured against the nature that was assumed, 42 nothing ever died so justly;
43 and so nothing was ever so wronged, 44 considering the person who suffered, 45 in whom such a nature was contracted.
**Cornish:**
40 An poen henna rag henna an crows a wra portha 41 pub dhe’n naturel a veu assums, a wra mesury, 42 nyns eus bythken tra morras kemmys yn just.
43 Ha henna nyns eus tra bythken a veu kemmys an gwrians, 44 ow selwel orth an person a wra soffrya, 45 ynno mayth a veu contract naturel avel henna.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
46 Però d’un atto uscir cose diverse: 47 ch’a Dio e a’ Giudei piacque una morte; 48 per lei tremò la terra e ’l ciel s’aperse.
query.result:
**English:**
46 But from one act diverse things came forth: 47 for to God and to the Jews one death was pleasing; 48 because of it the earth trembled and the sky opened.
**Cornish:**
46 Mes a-ugh unn gwrians a dheuth traow diverse: 47 rag dhe Duw ha dhe’n Yedhewon a veu lowen unn mernans; 48 rag henna an nor a wra krena ha’n nef a veu agrys.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
49 Non ti dee oramai parer più forte, 50 quando si dice che giusta vendetta 51 poscia vengiata fu da giusta corte.
query.result:
**English:**
49 It should not seem too difficult to you now, 50 when it is said that just vengeance 51 was subsequently avenged by a just court.
**Cornish:**
49 Nyns dhefsa bos dheugh parys moy kemmys kalet, 50 pub leverir bos venjans just a veu 51 wosa venjys gans unn lys just.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
52 Ma io veggi’ or la tua mente ristretta 53 di pensiero in pensier dentro ad un nodo, 54 del qual con gran disio solver s’aspetta.
query.result:
**English:**
52 But I see now your mind is constrained 53 from thought to thought within a knot, 54 from which it awaits to be freed with great desire.
**Cornish:**
52 Mes y’m a wel y’th poynt a-ugh y’th galon restrys 53 a-ugh poynt dhe bys poynt a-ugh unn nod, 54 a-ugh henna yma’th galon a wra goul orth y dhiskwedhes gans gerens meur.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
55 Tu dici: “Ben discerno ciò ch’i’ odo; 56 ma perché Dio volesse, m’è occulto, 57 a nostra redenzion pur questo modo”.
query.result:
**English:**
55 You say: “I clearly understand what I hear; 56 but why God willed it, is hidden from me, 57 for our redemption, precisely in this way”.
**Cornish:**
55 Thowgh lever: “Y’m a wel a-ugh henna a’m a glew; 56 mes rag pyth a wra lowen dhe Duw, henna a wra kudhes dhym, 57 rag an redencion agan, yn an fordh ma a wra henna”.

Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.

82anditsdignityneverreturns, 83unlessitfills,whereguiltempties, 84againstwrongfulpleasurewithjustpunishments.**Cornish:**79Anpekadowhaganworthughandhadisfrank, 80haganworthughandhadisfrank, 81ragaganworthughandhadisfrank, 82haganworthughandhadisfrank, 83haganworthughandhadisfrank, 84haganworthughandhadisfrank.**Cornish:**79Anpekadowhaganworthughandhadisfrank, 80hagansymper, 81ragaganworthughandhadisfrank, 82haganworthughandhadisfrank, 83haganworthughandhadisfrank, 84haganworthughandhadisfrank.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
85 Vostra natura, quando peccò tota 86 nel seme suo, da queste dignitadi, 87 come di paradiso, fu remota;
88 né ricovrar potiensi, se tu badi 89 ben sottilmente, per alcuna via, 90 sanza passar per un di questi guadi:
91 o che Dio solo per sua cortesia 92 dimesso avesse, o che l’uom per sé isso 93 avesse sodisfatto a sua follia.
query.result:
**English:**85Yournature,whensinitotally, 86initsseed,fromthesedignities, 87asfromparadise,wasremoved;
88norcoulditrecoverthem,ifyouobserve 89verycarefully,byanymeans, 90withoutpassingthroughoneofthesefords:
91eitherthatGodalonethroughhiscourtesy 92hadpardoned,orthatmanbyhimself 93hadmadeamendsforhisfolly.**Cornish:**85Annaturethow,panvonekpas, 86y'gansymper,aganwedhowma, 87velparadys,vedhrevas.
88Ha'ganworthughandhadisfrank, 89ragaganworthughandhadisfrank, 90ragaganworthughandhadisfrank:
91owhagandhuwlowpurvethkourtesy, 92dhevesas,owhagandhuwpurvethisso, 93dhevesas,owhagandhuwpurvethisso.

Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
94 Ficca mo l’occhio per entro l’abisso 95 de l’etterno consiglio, quanto puoi 96 al mio parlar distrettamente fisso.
query.result: **English:**94Fixnowyoureyeintotheabyss 95ofeternalcounsel,asmuchasyoucan, 96withyourattentionfirmlyfixedtomywords.**Cornish:**94Fykkanowganlagasynsi'ganabys, 95aganfordhoma,kemmysygallos, 96ganworthughandhadisfrank.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
97 Non potea l’uomo ne’ termini suoi 98 mai sodisfar, per non potere ir giuso 99 con umiltate obedïendo poi,
100 quanto disobediendo intese ir suso; 101 e questa è la cagion per che l’uom fue 102 da poter sodisfar per sé dischiuso.
query.result:
**English:**
97 Man could not, in his own terms, 98 ever make amends, because he could not go down 99 with humility, obeying afterwards,
100 as much as he intended to go up by disobeying; 101 and this is the reason why man was 102 allowed to make amends for himself.
**Cornish:**
97 Nyns ollas an den yn y germynnow 98 byth sodisfya, rag na alla gans isel 99 gans umilite obedya wosa,
100 Kemmys a-dhiwedhas intesas mos dhesel; 101 ha henna yw an acheson rag an den veu 102 a alla gans y honen sodisfya diskudhas.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
103 Dunque a Dio convenia con le vie sue 104 riparar l’omo a sua intera vita, 105 dico con l’una, o ver con amendue.
query.result:
**English:**
103 Therefore it was necessary for God, in his ways, 104 to restore man to his full life, 105 I say with one way, or indeed with both.
**Cornish:**
103 Rag henna veu rekis dhe Dhew gans y fordhow 104 ripara an den dhe y vywans leun, 105 Me a lever gans unn fordh, po gans an dhew.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
106 Ma perché l’ovra tanto è più gradita 107 da l’operante, quanto più appresenta 108 de la bontà del core ond’ ell’ è uscita,
109 la divina bontà che ’l mondo imprenta, 110 di proceder per tutte le sue vie, 111 a rilevarvi suso, fu contenta.
query.result:
**English:**
106 But because the work is all the more appreciated 107 by the worker, the more it shows 108 the goodness of the heart from which it came,
109 the divine goodness that imprints the world, 110 in proceeding through all its ways, 111 was content to raise you up again.
**Cornish:**
106 Mes rag an ober yw moy grasys 107 dhe’n oberor, kemmys moy a-dhiwedh 108 a’n dhasowder an golon a-dhyworth henna,
109 An dhasowder dhiwin a brint an bys, 110 a-dhalleth dre oll y fordhow, 111 veu lowen dhe’th vos dhesel.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
112 Né tra l’ultima notte e ’l primo die 113 sì alto o sì magnifico processo, 114 o per l’una o per l’altra, fu o fie:
115 ché più largo fu Dio a dar sé stesso 116 per far l’uom sufficiente a rilevarsi, 117 che s’elli avesse sol da sé dimesso;
118 e tutti li altri modi erano scarsi 119 a la giustizia, se ’l Figliuol di Dio 120 non fosse umilïato ad incarnarsi.
query.result:
**English:**
112 Neither between the last night and the first day 113 was there ever so lofty or magnificent a process, 114 either through the one way or the other, nor will there be:
115 for God was more generous in giving himself 116 to make man capable of rising again, 117 than if he had merely forgiven him;
118 and all other ways were insufficient 119 for justice, if the Son of God 120 had not humbled himself to become incarnate.
**Cornish:**
112 Nag eus ynter an nosva diwettha ha’n jydh kynsa 113 proses kemmys ughel po kemmys a-dhiwedh, 114 po dre’n unn fordh po dre’n aral, veu po a fyth:
115 Rag moy lew veu Dhew dhe roi henna honen 116 rag gul an den a-dhiwedh dhe vos dhesel, 117 Genver vyth ef a via dimittis a-unnik;
118 Ha oll an fordhow aral veu skars 119 dhe’n justijs, marnas Mab an Dhew 120 na via umilis dhe enkorna.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
121 Or per empierti bene ogne disio, 122 ritorno a dichiararti in alcun loco, 123 perché tu veggi lì così com’ io.
query.result:
**English:**
121 Now, to fully satisfy every desire, 122 I return to explain to you in some place, 123 so that you may see there just as I do.
**Cornish:**
121 Mes rag gul empinya oll disir a-dhiwedh, 122 Me a dhehwel dhe’th displegya yn unn le, 123 Rag welyth henna eno dell ow kewsel.

**English:**
130 The angels, brother, and the pure land 131 in which you are, can be said to have been created, 132 just as they are, in their entire being;
133 but the elements that you have named 134 and the things that are made from them 135 are informed by created power.
**Cornish:**
130 An eleth, froder, ha’n pow sur, 131 Yn le mayth tys, a yllir lever bos kreadys, 132 Dell ow ens, yn aga bos ollans.
133 Mes an elvennow a-dhenvys 134 Ha’n traow ma a wra dhe’n elvennow 135 A wra furvys dhe greys kreadys.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
136 Creata fu la materia ch’elli hanno; 137 creata fu la virtù informante 138 in queste stelle che ’ntorno a lor vanno.
query.result:
**English:**
136 The matter that they have was created; 137 the informing power was created 138 in these stars that go around them.
**Cornish:**
136 Kreadys veu an mater a-dhenvys; 137 Kreadys veu an greys a-furvys 138 Yn an ster ma a wra a-dro dhe’n elvennow.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
145 E quinci puoi argomentare ancora 146 vostra resurrezion, se tu ripensi 147 come l’umana carne fessi allora
148 che li primi parenti intrambo fensi».
query.result:
**English:**
145 And from this you can also infer 146 your resurrection, if you think back 147 to how human flesh was made at the time
148 when both the first parents were made.
**Cornish:**
145 Ha dhyworth henna yllith argumentya 146 Aga resurrektijon, marnas tys a-bys 147 Kemmys veu gwres an korf denel henna
148 Pan veu gwres an kynsa parentow oll.
